Co-authored by: @jjaassoonn 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [90c9112a64](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20640/commits/90c9112a646d9c66da5446fc4257b6ae0c27f447)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Morita.Basic` (new file)|1169|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ IsMoritaEquivalent`
`+ of_ringEquiv`
`+ refl`
`+ symm`
`+ trans`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Since this is data, maybe just call it MoritaEquivalence?
Also it would be unfortunate if we have to introduce a free universe parameter `v` here. I would expect `v = max u₁ u₂` would imply equivalence for any `v`? The two rings and the projective bimodules mentioned on [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morita_equivalence#Criteria_for_equivalence) are all comparable in size, it appears.

Also I think it would be appropriate to include a proof that any matrix ring over R is Morita equivalent to R.

By the way, it looks like Morita equivalence would be another great motivation for generalizations to allow tensor products over a noncommutative ring.
the proof that the matrix ring over R is equivalent to R will be our next PR it's a bit long

I think this does not need to be a one field structure and be `def MoritaEquivalence (R : Type u₁) (S : Type u₂) [Ring R] [Ring S] := ModuleCat.{v} R ≌ ModuleCat.{v} S`.

And I think it is fine that this depends on an additional universe, but I don't think the `IsMoritaEquivalent` predicate should. We don't have countably many different notions of Morita equivalences in the literature.

> I think this does not need to be a one field structure and be def MoritaEquivalence (R : Type u₁) (S : Type u₂) [Ring R] [Ring S] := ModuleCat.{v} R ≌ ModuleCat.{v} S

In this case, I wonder if this definition should be inlined.

> I would expect v = max u₁ u₂ would imply equivalence for any v?

It seems that by forcing `v = max u₁ u₂` makes writing `IsMoritaEquivalent.trans` difficult because the difference between `max u1 u2`, `max u2 u3` and `max u1 u3`
I have added a `TODO` to remove universe restriction in `IsMoritaEquivalent.trans` once we have more equivalent definitions for morita euiqvalence
Add: Morita equivalence in terms of existence of an invertible bimodule.

```suggestion
-- TODO: We have restricted universe here, but if we defined Morita Equivalence in terms of
-- idempotents, we could remove the restriction.
```
Not sure what the intent was, please check.

Presumably you could lift the universe restriction already, using `R ≃+* ULift R` and the below. Maybe it would be helpful to state that Morita equivalence is equivalent to `Nonempty (ModuleCat.{max w (max u₁ u₂)} R ≌ ModuleCat.{max w (max u₁ u₂)} S)` for any fixed `w`.

But optional, generalizing universes can wait if you prefer!

> Maybe it would be helpful to state that Morita equivalence is equivalent to `Nonempty (ModuleCat.{max w (max u₁ u₂)} R ≌ ModuleCat.{max w (max u₁ u₂)} S)`

How would you go about proving that? It doesn't seem to be the case that `ModuleCat.{max w (max u₁ u₂)} R` can be obtained from `ModuleCat.{max u₁ u₂} R` by some categorical construction.

I've figured out one way; please feel free to suggest simplifications or better approaches.

Let F be an equivalence from `ModuleCat.{v} R` to `ModuleCat.{v} S` with inverse G; we want to find explicit descriptions of F and G that can be lifted to higher universes. Let `M : ModuleCat.{v} R`, we have F(M) ≃ Hom_S(S, F(M)) ≃ Hom_R(G(S), M) which is the desired description, except that we need an S^mop-action on G(S) to obtain a S-action on Hom_R(G(S), M). This can be obtained because S^mop is simply Hom_S(S,S) ≃ Hom_R(G(S), G(S)). Similarly we obtain G(N) ≃ Hom_S(F(R), N) as R-modules.

Now we simply take Hom_R(G(S), -) to be the definition of F in the higher universe, and take Hom_S(F(R), -) to be the definition of G. It remains to construct a natural equivalence Hom_S(F(R), Hom_R(G(S), M)) ≃ M of R-modules (and another symmetric one of S-modules). We already have this equivalence if M lies in universe `v` from the (co)unitIso of the equivalence F/G, in particular if M is finitely generated, but any M (even in higher universe) is a direct limit of f.g. submodules ([Module.fgSystem.equiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Colimit/Finiteness.html#Module.fgSystem.equiv)), so it suffices to show Hom_S(F(R), -) and Hom_R(G(S), -) preserve filtered colimits in the higher universe, for which it suffices to show F(R) and G(S) are finitely presented S-module and R-module respectively. (Injectivity of `colim Hom(M,Nᵢ) → Hom(M, colim Nᵢ)` requires only M to be f.g., but surjectivity requires finite presentation.) To show e.g. F(R) is finitely presented as an S-module, we can take some directed system of finitely presented modules (in the universe of S, so we need `v ≥ u₂`) with colimit F(R); we have that Hom_S(F(R), F(R)) is the colimit of Hom_S(F(R), -) applied to this directed system, because Hom_S(F(R), -) is simply the equivalence G, which certainly preserves colimits. So the identity map in Hom_S(F(R), F(R)) comes from some Hom_S(F(R), M) with M finitely presented, so F(R) is a direct summand of a finitely presented module and so is itself finitely presented (one can mimic the proof of [Module.finitePresentation_of_projective](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/FinitePresentation.html#Module.finitePresentation_of_projective) here).

Looks like we're temporarily spared from tensor products over noncommutative rings ...
Thanks for the suggestion, I have changed the `TODO` to reflect the existence of this arguemnt

```suggestion
-- `max u₁ u₂`, `max u₂ u₃` vs `max u₁ u₃`. But if we once we proved the definition of Morita
-- equivalence is equivalent to the existence of a full idempotent element, we can remove this
-- restriction in the universe.
-- Or alternatively, @alreadydone one has sketched an argument on how the universe restriction can be
-- removed via a categorical argument,
```

Just mentioning that #20531 introduces the corner eRe associated to an idempotent element `e : R`. (According to Wikipedia, the characterization in terms of full idempotents says that S is isomorphic to `eMatₙ(R)e` for some full idempotent e in Matₙ(R).)

pullRequest.title: feat(RingTheory/Morita/Basic): Define Morita Equivalence

source.title: feat: categorical description of center of a ring
